metadata.case_name: J.K. Cotton Spinning & Weaving Mills Co., Ltd. v. Respondents

facts.text: Industrial dispute arose between appellant J.K. Cotton Spinning & Weaving Mills Co., Ltd. and its employees (respondents) referred by U.P. Government to Adjudicator, Kanpur on November 30, 1953.

Dispute covered two items: (1) dismissal of gardener Mali Badri, claimed unlawful, entitled to reinstatement with wages; (2) claims by 10 Malis for dear food allowance, weekly holidays, leave with wages.

10 Malis appointed by appellant for maintenance of gardens attached to bungalows of officers and Director within Mills compound; not gardens of Mills factory itself; wages Rs.450 total monthly, bulk paid by appellant; supervised by appellant's clerk; no control by officers.

Before Adjudicator, appellant contended Malis not workmen under U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947; G.O. No. 3754 LL XVIII-894 L-1948 dated Dec 6, 1948 inapplicable as Malis not industrial employees; rejected other claims.

Adjudicator held Malis are workmen; Badri's dismissal unjustified, ordered reinstatement with half wages Rs.45 p.m. as compensation; denied dear food allowance, weekly holidays, leave with wages to Malis. Award dated May 31, 1954.

Appellant appealed to Labour Appellate Tribunal (Appeal No. 300/1954) disputing Badri as workman and dismissal; respondents appealed (No. 274/1954) on dear food etc. Tribunal dismissed appellant's appeal; allowed respondents' partly: dear food allowance yes, weekly holiday no, leave per s.79 Factories Act principle, full wages to Badri. Decision July 15, 1955.
Appellant filed writ petition No.1006/1955 in Allahabad High Court under Art.226 challenging Tribunal decision; dismissed March 10, 1958 as infructuous since Lucknow Bench ceased to exist.
Present appeals to Supreme Court by special leave: CA 480/1962 against HC order, CA 481/1962 against Tribunal; CA 480 not pressed.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Malis are workmen under s.2 of U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 (via s.2(s) Industrial Disputes Act, 1947)?
Whether Malis are industrial employees entitled to dear food allowance under G.O. No.3754 LL XVIII-894 L-1948 dated Dec 6, 1948?
Whether Malis entitled to leave with wages on grounds of social justice, despite Factories Act and U.P. Shops Act not applying?

petitioner_arguments.text: Malish not workmen under s.2(s) ID Act as not employed in any industry (spinning/weaving); only directly in industry qualify.
Malish not industrial employees under G.O.; G.O. applies only to industrial employees, narrower than workmen.
Leave claim based specifically on Factories Act s.79 and U.P. Shops Act, inapplicable to Malish; social justice not valid ground.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Factories Act s.79; social justice irrelevant per precedents

respondent_arguments.text: Dismissal of Badri unlawful; entitled to reinstatement with full wages; Malish entitled to dear food, holidays, leave.
Malish are workmen and industrial employees.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.2 U.P. Industrial Disputes Act; G.O.

court_reasoning.text: Malish employed in operations incidental to main industry (spinning/weaving), e.g., maintaining gardens of company-provided bungalows for officers is amenity like transport buses; not remote/indirect.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Employed in any industry includes incidental connection; modern industry complex, totality constitutes industry.

court_reasoning.text: Consistent view of industrial adjudication that such Malish are workmen; cited Labour Appellate Tribunal cases.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Reluctant to interfere with consistent course unless plainly erroneous.

court_reasoning.text: G.O. binds industries and workmen therein (per para 1); industrial/clerical in para 2 clarifies table categories, not limits; issued under Act referring to s.2 workmen.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Scheme extends to all workmen under s.2.

court_reasoning.text: Leave claim general, not limited to specific Acts; social justice valid, integral to industrial law for harmony.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Social justice pragmatic, resolves competing claims fairly.

holdings.text: Malish are workmen under s.2(s) ID Act as engaged in incidental operations to main industry.
Malish entitled to dear food allowance under G.O. as workmen.
Malish entitled to leave with wages on principles of social justice akin to s.79 Factories Act.

precedents_cited.relevance: Mali on company payroll looking after officer bungalow is workman under s.2(s)

precedents_cited.relevance: Mali for Managing Director not domestic servant, is workman

precedents_cited.relevance: Relevance of social justice in industrial adjudication

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 (No.14 of 1947)
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of workman: employed in any industry to do manual etc. work

statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for writ petition to High Court

outcome.summary: Civil Appeal No.481/1962 dismissed upholding Labour Appellate Tribunal; Malish are workmen entitled to dear food allowance and leave on social justice; CA 480/1962 also dismissed as not pressed.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellant; confirms reinstatement/full wages to Badri, dear food/leave to Malish

key_quotes.text: "an employee who is engaged in any work or operation which is incidentally connected with the main industry of the employer would be a workman"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on definition of workman including incidental operations

key_quotes.text: "the concept of social justice has now become such an integral part of industrial law that it would be idle for any party to suggest that industrial adjudication can or should ignore the claims of social justice"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms role of social justice in industrial disputes

key_quotes.text: "industrial employees should be understood in the same comprehensive sense as the word workman under s.2(s) of the Industrial Disputes Act"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets G.O. scope co-extensive with workmen definition
